title: Isaiah Chapter 7 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 7 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 7 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 7.

questions.question: Who was king of Judah during the time Rezin and Pekah went up to war against Jerusalem?
options: Ahaz
Jotham
Uzziah
Remaliah
questions.correctAnswer: Ahaz
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:1 states that it was in the days of Ahaz, the son of Jotham, king of Judah.

questions.question: What two kingdoms were confederate against Judah as reported to the house of David?
options: Syria and Ephraim
Judah and Egypt
Assyria and Babylon
Israel and Moab
questions.correctAnswer: Syria and Ephraim
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:2 reports that Syria was confederate with Ephraim against Judah.

questions.question: Where was Isaiah instructed by the LORD to meet Ahaz?
options: At the end of the conduit of the upper pool
At the temple in Jerusalem
On the mountaintop
In the marketplace
questions.correctAnswer: At the end of the conduit of the upper pool
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:3 commands Isaiah to meet Ahaz at the end of the conduit of the upper pool in the highway of the fuller's field.

questions.question: What did the LORD tell Isaiah to say to Ahaz regarding the threat from Rezin and the son of Remaliah?
options: Fear not, neither be fainthearted
Prepare for battle immediately
Flee the city at once
Build a great wall
questions.correctAnswer: Fear not, neither be fainthearted
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:4 instructs to tell Ahaz to be quiet and not fear the fierce anger of Rezin and the son of Remaliah.

questions.question: Who was the planned king that Syria and Ephraim wanted to set in the midst of Judah?
options: The son of Tabeal
Ahaz
Remaliah's son
The king of Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: The son of Tabeal
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:6 mentions that their evil counsel was to make a breach in Judah and set the son of Tabeal as king.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 7:8, which city is called the head of Syria?
options: Damascus
Samaria
Jerusalem
Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: Damascus
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:8 states that the head of Syria is Damascus.

questions.question: What sign did the LORD say He would give according to Isaiah 7:14?
options: A virgin shall conceive and bear a son
A great earthquake will shake the land
The sun will be darkened
The rivers will turn to blood
questions.correctAnswer: A virgin shall conceive and bear a son
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:14 declares that the Lord Himself will give a sign: a virgin shall conceive and bear a son called Immanuel.

questions.question: What was Ahaz's response when asked to ask a sign of the LORD?
options: I will not ask, neither will I tempt the LORD
I will ask for a sign from heaven
I will ask for an army
I will ask for peace
questions.correctAnswer: I will not ask, neither will I tempt the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:12 records Ahaz saying he will not ask or tempt the LORD.

questions.question: What food is mentioned in Isaiah 7:15 that the child will eat?
options: Butter and honey
Bread and wine
Fish and olives
Milk and figs
questions.correctAnswer: Butter and honey
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:15 says the child shall eat butter and honey to know to refuse evil and choose good.

questions.question: Who is described as the head of Ephraim in Isaiah 7:9?
options: Remaliah's son
Rezin
Ahaz
Jotham
questions.correctAnswer: Remaliah's son
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:9 identifies the head of Ephraim as Samaria and the head of Samaria as Remaliah's son.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 7:7 says the evil counsel of Syria and Ephraim will surely stand and succeed.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:7 states that it shall not stand nor come to pass, referring to their evil counsel.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 7:16 says the land that Ahaz abhors will be forsaken by both kings before the child knows to refuse evil and choose good.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:16 clearly states the land that Ahaz abhors will be forsaken by both kings before the child understands good and evil.

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 7:11, the LORD told Ahaz to ask a sign from the LORD his God either in the depth or in the height above.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:11 records the LORD telling Ahaz to ask for a sign from the LORD either in the depth or height.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Isaiah 7:14: 'Therefore the Lord himself shall give you a sign; Behold, a ______ shall conceive, and bear a son, and shall call his name Immanuel.'
options: virgin
woman
queen
prophet
questions.correctAnswer: virgin
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:14 specifies that a virgin shall conceive and bear a son called Immanuel.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Isaiah 7:15: 'Butter and ______ shall he eat, that he may know to refuse the evil, and choose the good.'
options: honey
milk
bread
wine
questions.correctAnswer: honey
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:15 mentions butter and honey as the food the child shall eat.

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 7 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 7 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Isaiah 7, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God in difficult times?
options: God will not let the evil plans against His people succeed
We must rely on our own strength to overcome enemies
It is best to avoid all conflicts to keep peace
God’s promises only apply to ancient times
questions.correctAnswer: God will not let the evil plans against His people succeed
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:7 says, 'It shall not stand, neither shall it come to pass,' assuring us that God will not allow the hostile plans against Judah to succeed. This encourages faith and trust in God's protection (Isaiah 7:4-7, 7:9).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 7 teach us about responding to fear and anxiety in faith?
options: Be quiet, do not fear or lose heart in the face of danger
Hide away from challenges to avoid stress
Rely on human alliances for security
Ignore the problem and hope it resolves
questions.correctAnswer: Be quiet, do not fear or lose heart in the face of danger
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:4 instructs Ahaz to 'Take heed, and be quiet; fear not, neither be fainthearted,' showing believers the importance of calm trust in God rather than succumbing to fear (Isaiah 7:4-5, 7:10-11).

questions.question: A believer feels overwhelmed by opposition and doubts God’s promises. What encouragement does Isaiah 7 offer about God’s faithfulness?
options: God will provide a sign as a confirmation of His promise
God’s promises depend on our perfect faith
We should question God’s will regularly
Signs from God are only for prophets
questions.correctAnswer: God will provide a sign as a confirmation of His promise
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:11-14 shows God’s willingness to give a sign to confirm His promises, demonstrating His faithfulness even when people doubt (Isaiah 7:11-14, 7:13).

questions.question: How does the prophecy of a virgin conceiving and bearing a son in Isaiah 7 relate to living with hope in God’s salvation?
options: It points to God’s direct intervention and salvation through Immanuel
It encourages self-reliance instead of divine help
It predicts only political changes
It is a warning to avoid marriage and family
questions.correctAnswer: It points to God’s direct intervention and salvation through Immanuel
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:14 promises a miraculous sign: a virgin will bear a son named Immanuel, meaning 'God with us,' symbolizing God’s nearness and salvation (Isaiah 7:14-15, 7:16).

questions.question: A Christian is struggling with making good choices. What practical wisdom does Isaiah 7 offer about discerning and choosing good over evil?
options: The child will learn to refuse evil and choose good, showing growth in moral discernment
Good and evil are relative and depend on circumstances
Avoiding decisions is better than making mistakes
Only elders can teach what is good
questions.correctAnswer: The child will learn to refuse evil and choose good, showing growth in moral discernment
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:15 describes the child eating butter and honey to know how to refuse evil and choose good, illustrating that spiritual maturity involves learning to discern right from wrong (Isaiah 7:15-16).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 7 teach about humility and dependence on God rather than political alliances?
options: Do not rely on Syria and Ephraim because their plans will fail
Trust in military alliances for security
Use diplomacy to please all neighbors
Seek power through human strength alone
questions.correctAnswer: Do not rely on Syria and Ephraim because their plans will fail
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:5-9 explains that the alliance of Syria and Ephraim against Judah will not succeed, teaching that trusting in God rather than worldly alliances is wise (Isaiah 7:5-9).

questions.question: A believer hesitates to ask God for a sign of guidance. What does Isaiah 7 reveal about God’s openness to our requests and Ahaz’s response?
options: God invites us to ask for signs, but Ahaz refused to ask
God never gives signs to people
Asking God for signs shows lack of faith
Only prophets can ask God for signs
questions.correctAnswer: God invites us to ask for signs, but Ahaz refused to ask
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:11-13 shows God inviting Ahaz to ask for a sign, but Ahaz refuses, teaching us that God welcomes our requests and desires our trust (Isaiah 7:11-13).

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 7 teaches that God’s plans for His people cannot be thwarted by human opposition.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:7 clearly states that the plans of Syria and Ephraim will not stand or come to pass, showing God's sovereign control over human affairs (Isaiah 7:7, 7:8-9).

questions.question: True or False: Ahaz was willing to seek a sign from God to confirm His promises.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:12 records Ahaz refusing to ask for a sign, demonstrating a lack of trust and willingness to test God (Isaiah 7:11-13).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Isaiah 7, the child who will be born shall be called ________.
options: Immanuel
Messiah
David
Emmanuel
questions.correctAnswer: Immanuel
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:14 states the child shall be called Immanuel, meaning 'God with us,' signifying God's presence with His people (Isaiah 7:14-15).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 7 instruct us about perseverance through trials and trusting God’s timing?
options: Before the child learns good and evil, the threatening kings will be gone
We should give up if problems last too long
God’s timing is unpredictable and unreliable
Trials mean God has abandoned us
questions.correctAnswer: Before the child learns good and evil, the threatening kings will be gone
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:16 indicates that before the child can discern good and evil, the enemies will be no more, teaching patience and trust in God's timing (Isaiah 7:14-16).

questions.question: A believer is struggling to forgive and love neighbors who oppose them. What lesson from Isaiah 7 can guide them?
options: God’s protection and sovereignty invite us to love despite opposition
We should return harm for harm to protect ourselves
Forgiveness is only for close friends
Ignoring enemies is the best course
questions.correctAnswer: God’s protection and sovereignty invite us to love despite opposition
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7 speaks of God’s control over opposition and His faithfulness, encouraging believers to respond with trust and love rather than retaliation (Isaiah 7:7-9, 7:17-18).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 7 show the importance of humility and obedience in family and leadership?
options: Ahaz’s refusal to ask for a sign shows a failure to humbly seek God’s guidance
Leaders should rely on their own wisdom alone
Family and leadership should avoid involving God in decisions
Obedience is less important than political success
questions.correctAnswer: Ahaz’s refusal to ask for a sign shows a failure to humbly seek God’s guidance
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:12-13 highlights Ahaz’s refusal to ask God for a sign, teaching the need for humility and obedience in leadership and family life (Isaiah 7:10-13).

questions.question: What practical advice for daily living can be drawn from Isaiah 7’s description of the land becoming briers and thorns?
options: Neglect and disobedience lead to loss of blessings and hardship
Land will always produce fruit regardless of care
Briers and thorns are signs of God’s blessing
Abundance is guaranteed for all
questions.correctAnswer: Neglect and disobedience lead to loss of blessings and hardship
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:23-24 describes the land turning into briers and thorns, symbolizing the consequences of disobedience and neglect, encouraging stewardship and faithfulness (Isaiah 7:23-25).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 7 encourage believers regarding God’s provision even in difficult circumstances?
options: Even in hardship, there will be butter and honey to sustain the people
Provision depends solely on human effort
God withholds blessings during trials
We should not expect any provision in hard times
questions.correctAnswer: Even in hardship, there will be butter and honey to sustain the people
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:15 and 7:22 mention butter and honey, symbolizing God’s provision and sustenance even amidst trials, encouraging contentment and trust (Isaiah 7:15, 7:22).

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 7 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 7.

questions.question: Which two kings allied against Jerusalem during the days of Ahaz according to Isaiah 7?
options: Rezin king of Syria and Pekah son of Remaliah
David king of Judah and Solomon son of David
Hezekiah king of Judah and Hoshea king of Israel
Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon and Cyrus king of Persia
questions.correctAnswer: Rezin king of Syria and Pekah son of Remaliah
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:1 states that Rezin, king of Syria, and Pekah, son of Remaliah, king of Israel, went up against Jerusalem to war but could not prevail.

questions.question: In Isaiah 7, what metaphor is used to describe the movement of Ahaz’s heart and the heart of his people upon hearing the news of the alliance?
options: Trees of the wood moved with the wind
Waves of the sea tossed by the storm
Mountains shaken by an earthquake
Fire consuming dry grass
questions.correctAnswer: Trees of the wood moved with the wind
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:2 compares the stirring of Ahaz’s heart and his people's hearts to trees being moved by the wind, symbolizing instability and fear.

questions.question: What sign does the Lord give to Ahaz through Isaiah, as a foreshadowing of a Messianic prophecy?
options: A virgin shall conceive and bear a son called Immanuel
The sun will stand still
A rainbow after the flood
The parting of the Red Sea
questions.correctAnswer: A virgin shall conceive and bear a son called Immanuel
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:14 contains a typological prophecy that a virgin will conceive and bear a son named Immanuel, which is later referenced in the New Testament as a Messianic prophecy.

questions.question: What is the significance of the name 'Immanuel' given in Isaiah 7:14, in its Hebrew context?
options: God with us
Prince of Peace
Mighty Warrior
Everlasting Father
questions.correctAnswer: God with us
questions.explanation: The Hebrew name 'Immanuel' means 'God with us,' signifying God's presence among His people, a key theme in Isaiah 7:14 and throughout Scripture.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 7:8 use historical and geopolitical context to predict the fate of Ephraim?
options: Ephraim will be broken within 65 years
Ephraim will conquer Syria
Ephraim will form an unbreakable alliance
Ephraim will become the capital of Judah
questions.correctAnswer: Ephraim will be broken within 65 years
questions.explanation: The verse refers to the political headship of Damascus and Samaria and predicts Ephraim’s destruction within 65 years, highlighting historical realities of Israel’s downfall.

questions.question: What literary device is predominantly used in Isaiah 7:4 when describing Rezin and the son of Remaliah as 'two tails of these smoking firebrands'?
options: Metaphor
Simile
Alliteration
Hyperbole
questions.correctAnswer: Metaphor
questions.explanation: The phrase 'two tails of these smoking firebrands' is a metaphor illustrating the destructive threat posed by Rezin and Pekah.

questions.question: Which historical empire does Isaiah 7:17 predict will bring unprecedented days upon Ahaz and his people?
options: The king of Assyria
The Babylonian Empire
The Egyptian Pharaoh
The Medes and Persians
questions.correctAnswer: The king of Assyria
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:17 explicitly mentions the king of Assyria as the instrument of God’s judgment on Judah, forecasting Assyria's rise and dominance.

questions.question: True or False: Ahaz accepted the Lord's offer to ask for a sign as described in Isaiah 7.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:12 records Ahaz’s refusal to ask for a sign, saying he will not tempt the Lord.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 7:15, what foods will the child eat, and what is their symbolic significance?
options: Butter and honey, symbolizing knowledge to refuse evil and choose good
Bread and wine, symbolizing covenant
Figs and olives, symbolizing prosperity
Meat and fish, symbolizing strength
questions.correctAnswer: Butter and honey, symbolizing knowledge to refuse evil and choose good
questions.explanation: Verse 15 indicates butter and honey as the child's nourishment, symbols of sustenance and the moral discernment to reject evil and choose good.

questions.question: What is the implied consequence mentioned in Isaiah 7:16 before the child knows to refuse evil and choose good?
options: The land abhorred by Ahaz will be forsaken by both kings
The child will be taken captive
The enemy will be destroyed immediately
The land will prosper and multiply
questions.correctAnswer: The land abhorred by Ahaz will be forsaken by both kings
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:16 forecasts that before the child's moral development, the land that Ahaz detests will be abandoned by its two kings, indicating political collapse.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'razor that is hired' in Isaiah 7:20 within the cultural context of the ancient Near East?
options: It symbolizes Assyria's destructive power over Judah
It indicates a ritual cleansing by priests
It is a metaphor for agricultural tools
It refers to a weapon used in battle
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes Assyria's destructive power over Judah
questions.explanation: The hired razor, identified as the king of Assyria, symbolizes the instrument of divine judgment and destruction wielded against Judah.

questions.question: In Isaiah 7:18, the Lord is said to 'hiss for the fly in Egypt' and 'for the bee in Assyria.' What literary device is used here and what does it symbolize?
options: Metaphor symbolizing calling small but dangerous agents
Personification of animals representing enemies
Simile describing the sound of war
Hyperbole exaggerated to emphasize power
questions.correctAnswer: Metaphor symbolizing calling small but dangerous agents
questions.explanation: The 'fly' and 'bee' are metaphors for smaller yet harmful agents summoned to execute God's judgment, illustrating subtle but potent threats.

questions.question: What is the role of Shearjashub in Isaiah 7:3, and how does his presence emphasize the prophetic message?
options: He accompanies Isaiah, symbolizing 'a remnant shall return' which reinforces hope amid judgment
He leads the army against Syria
He is the king of Judah's advisor
He is a priest performing sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: He accompanies Isaiah, symbolizing 'a remnant shall return' which reinforces hope amid judgment
questions.explanation: Shearjashub's name means 'a remnant shall return,' and his presence with Isaiah underscores God's promise of preservation despite coming judgment.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 7:23-24 describe the transformation of the land, and what does this indicate about the aftermath of judgment?
options: Formerly cultivated lands will become briers and thorns, indicating desolation and loss of prosperity
The land will be flooded and fertile
The vineyards will flourish abundantly
The land will be conquered by new settlers
questions.correctAnswer: Formerly cultivated lands will become briers and thorns, indicating desolation and loss of prosperity
questions.explanation: These verses use imagery of overgrown briers and thorns to signify devastation and abandonment following divine judgment.

questions.question: Which New Testament passage explicitly references Isaiah 7:14's prophecy about the virgin birth?
options: Matthew 1:23
John 3:16
Luke 2:11
Acts 2:38
questions.correctAnswer: Matthew 1:23
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:23 quotes Isaiah 7:14 to affirm the virgin birth of Jesus Christ, demonstrating the intertextual fulfillment of prophecy.

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 7 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 7 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: Who were the two kings that went up toward Jerusalem to wage war against it during the days of Ahaz?
options: Rezin king of Syria and Pekah son of Remaliah king of Israel
Ahaz king of Judah and Jotham son of Uzziah
Remaliah king of Ephraim and Rezin king of Assyria
Jotham king of Judah and Rezin king of Syria
questions.correctAnswer: Rezin king of Syria and Pekah son of Remaliah king of Israel
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:1 clearly states that Rezin, king of Syria, and Pekah, son of Remaliah, king of Israel, went to war against Jerusalem. This highlights the historical context of the threat against Judah. This event connects to later New Testament references where Christ is the fulfillment of God's protection (Matthew 1:23; Luke 1:31).

questions.question: What was the reaction of the house of David upon hearing that Syria was allied with Ephraim?
options: Their hearts were moved like trees in the wind
They rejoiced and praised God
They immediately sought an alliance with Assyria
They prepared for peace negotiations
questions.correctAnswer: Their hearts were moved like trees in the wind
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:2 describes the fear and trembling of the house of David likened to trees shaken by the wind, illustrating human fear and frailty in the face of political threats, a common biblical theme (Psalm 1:3; Matthew 7:26-27).

questions.question: What instruction did the LORD give to Isaiah concerning his meeting with King Ahaz?
options: Go to meet Ahaz with your son Shearjashub at the upper pool
Warn Ahaz to prepare for war immediately
Tell Ahaz to flee Jerusalem
Advise Ahaz to form an alliance with Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: Go to meet Ahaz with your son Shearjashub at the upper pool
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:3 records God's command to Isaiah to meet Ahaz at a specific location with his son, symbolizing God's personal intervention and prophetic reassurance to leadership, reflecting God's providence (Jeremiah 1:11-12; Ezekiel 2:1).

questions.question: What did God tell Ahaz regarding the two kings who threatened Judah?
options: Fear not and be quiet; the threat will not stand
Gather your armies and prepare for battle
Seek help from Egypt to resist them
Offer tribute to the kings to avoid destruction
questions.correctAnswer: Fear not and be quiet; the threat will not stand
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:4-7 emphasize God's sovereign assurance that the plans of Rezin and Pekah will not succeed. This reflects God's attribute of faithfulness and protection (Psalm 46:1-3; Romans 8:31).

questions.question: What sign did God promise to give to the house of David as a reassurance?
options: A virgin shall conceive and bear a son called Immanuel
The sun shall stand still in the sky
The enemies will be swallowed by the earth
A new temple shall be built in Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: A virgin shall conceive and bear a son called Immanuel
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:14 prophesies the miraculous birth of Immanuel, meaning 'God with us,' a foundational messianic prophecy fulfilled in Jesus Christ (Matthew 1:22-23; Luke 1:26-35). It reveals God's incarnation, a core Christian doctrine.

questions.question: How is the child named Immanuel described in terms of his early diet, and what is the spiritual significance?
options: Butter and honey, to know to refuse evil and choose good
Bread and water, symbolizing humility
Milk and fruit, representing nourishment
Meat and wine, indicating strength
questions.correctAnswer: Butter and honey, to know to refuse evil and choose good
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:15 states the child will eat butter and honey, symbolizing the sweetness of God's provision and the moral ability to reject evil and choose good, reflecting sanctification and wisdom (Proverbs 3:13-18; Hebrews 5:14).

questions.question: What consequence does Isaiah say will occur before the child knows to refuse evil and choose good?
options: The land despised by Ahaz will be forsaken by both kings
The temple will be destroyed
Jerusalem will be taken by the enemy
The people will be exiled to Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: The land despised by Ahaz will be forsaken by both kings
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:16 foretells that before the child matures, the lands Ahaz fears will be abandoned by their kings, demonstrating God's control over history and judgment (2 Kings 16:9; Jeremiah 25:9).

questions.question: Which foreign power does the LORD say will bring unprecedented hardship upon Judah, Ahaz, and his house?
options: The king of Assyria
The king of Babylon
The king of Egypt
The king of Moab
questions.correctAnswer: The king of Assyria
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:17 announces that Assyria will bring days of unparalleled trouble, illustrating God's sovereign use of nations to accomplish His purposes (Isaiah 10:5-7; Habakkuk 1:6).

questions.question: What symbolic action involving a razor does the LORD describe in Isaiah 7:20?
options: The Lord will shave with a hired razor, the king of Assyria, consuming the head and beard
The priests will shave their heads as a sign of mourning
The people will shave their beards to show repentance
The elders will shave their hair in celebration
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord will shave with a hired razor, the king of Assyria, consuming the head and beard
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:20 uses the razor as a metaphor for Assyria's destructive invasion, symbolizing God's judgment executed through foreign powers (Jeremiah 50:17; Ezekiel 5:1-4).

questions.question: What agricultural change does Isaiah predict in Isaiah 7:23-24 as a consequence of the coming judgment?
options: Vineyards will become briars and thorns, and men will come with bows and arrows
Fields will produce abundant crops and vineyards will flourish
Trees will bear fruit year-round
Fertile lands will be restored and cultivated by many
questions.correctAnswer: Vineyards will become briars and thorns, and men will come with bows and arrows
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:23-24 depicts desolation and warfare replacing fruitful agriculture, illustrating the devastating effects of sin and judgment on the land (Joel 1:7; Micah 7:1).

questions.question: What theological truth is conveyed by God's invitation to Ahaz to ask for a sign from the LORD, 'either in the depth or in the height above'?
options: God's willingness to reveal His power and sovereignty to His people
God's indifference to human requests
God's hiddenness and refusal to communicate
God's command for Ahaz to rely solely on human wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: God's willingness to reveal His power and sovereignty to His people
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:11 shows God's openness to provide a miraculous sign, reflecting His communicative nature and sovereign authority (Exodus 3:12; Psalm 19:1; Hebrews 2:4).

questions.question: How did King Ahaz respond to the LORD's offer to ask for a sign, and what does this reveal about his faith?
options: He refused, saying he would not test the LORD
He eagerly asked for a sign immediately
He sought a sign from Egypt instead
He ignored the LORD's instruction completely
questions.correctAnswer: He refused, saying he would not test the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:12 records Ahaz's refusal, revealing a lack of faith and trust in God's promises, a common human response to divine assurance (Numbers 20:12; Hebrews 3:12-19).

questions.question: What is the meaning of the name 'Immanuel' given to the child in Isaiah 7:14, and how does it relate to Christology?
options: God with us, signifying God's presence incarnate in Jesus
Mighty Warrior, symbolizing military strength
Prince of Peace, indicating future peace
Everlasting Father, denoting eternal nature
questions.correctAnswer: God with us, signifying God's presence incarnate in Jesus
questions.explanation: The name 'Immanuel' means 'God with us' (Isaiah 7:14), which is a profound Christological title fulfilled in Jesus Christ (Matthew 1:23), affirming the incarnation and God's redemptive presence.

questions.question: What does the prophecy in Isaiah 7:18 about the LORD hissing for the fly and the bee symbolize in the context of eschatology?
options: God summoning distant nations to execute judgment
Peace and harmony among nations
The gathering of Israel for restoration
The coming of the Holy Spirit on Pentecost
questions.correctAnswer: God summoning distant nations to execute judgment
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:18 uses symbolic imagery of flies and bees to represent foreign armies summoned by God to bring judgment, reflecting eschatological themes of divine justice (Joel 2:1-11; Revelation 9:3-10).

questions.question: In Isaiah 7:9, what warning does the LORD give about faith and establishment?
options: If you will not believe, you shall not be established
Trust in your own strength and you will prosper
Ignore the threats and you will be safe
The enemy will fall without any intervention
questions.correctAnswer: If you will not believe, you shall not be established
questions.explanation: Isaiah 7:9 conveys the necessity of faith for stability, a theological principle echoed in Hebrews 11:6 and James 2:19, emphasizing belief as foundational for God's covenantal blessings.
